questions.text: A patient with ulcerative colitis is experiencing three episodes of bleeding in stools per day but is otherwise stable. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-Aminosalicylic acid.

 

5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis, especially in a stable patient who is experiencing active symptoms like bleeding. It works as an anti-inflammatory agent in the colon and is effective in inducing and maintaining remission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5-Fluorouracil: This is a chemotherapeutic agent and is not used for treating ulcerative colitis. It's primarily used in cancer treatment.

 

Option C. Budesonide: While budesonide, a corticosteroid, is used in ulcerative colitis, it's generally reserved for more severe cases or when 5-ASA is ineffective. In a stable patient, it may not be the first choice.

 

Option D. 6-Mercaptopurine: This is an immunosuppressant used in ulcerative colitis primarily for maintenance therapy or in patients who haven't responded to other treatments, not typically as a first-line treatment in a stable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis and is effective in reducing inflammation and maintaining remission in stable patients experiencing active symptoms.

choices.text: Time interval between S2 and the opening snap

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with mitral stenosis is being evaluated. Which clinical finding best indicates the severity of the condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Time interval between S2 and the opening snap

 

Explanation:

 

The S2-OS (second heart sound to opening snap) interval is the best indicator of mitral stenosis severity:

 

  • Mild MS: S2-OS interval is longer (~100 ms or more)
  • Severe MS: S2-OS interval is short (~60 ms or less), indicating higher left atrial pressure

 

The earlier the opening snap occurs, the more severe the stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muffled heart sounds: Seen in pericardial effusion, cardiac tamponade, not mitral stenosis

 

Option B. Loud S1: Common in MS, but may become soft in severe cases due to valve calcification

 

Option C. S3 gallop: Associated with heart failure, mitral regurgitation, not mitral stenosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

The S2-OS interval is the best clinical indicator of mitral stenosis severity, as a shorter interval reflects higher left atrial pressure and more severe disease progression.

questions.text: Which type of virus is rubella? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Togavirus

 

Rubella belongs to the Togaviridae family.

 

Rubella (German measles)

 

  • Causative organism belongs to family Togaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks
  • Rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post infectious thrombocytopenia
  • Most serious complication: Encephalitis
  • Vaccination: 27/3 live attenuated

 

Congenital rubella syndrome:

 

  • When a woman in the 1st trimester gets infected with rubella, the resulting complications may include miscarriage, fetal death, premature delivery, or live birth with congenital defects.
  • The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataract, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome.
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term "blueberry muffin syndrome."

 

Expanded rubella syndrome:

 

  • Some babies present with several other features like hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions constituting the expanded rubella syndrome.
  • This term also refers to a baby with metastatic neuroblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flavivirus: This group includes viruses like the West Nile virus and Dengue virus, not Rubella.

 

Option C. Paramyxovirus: Includes viruses like measles and mumps, which are clinically distinct from rubella.

 

Option D. Orthomyxovirus: This is the family of viruses that includes the influenza viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rubella, commonly known as German measles, is caused by a virus that belongs to the Togaviridae family, specifically the genus Rubivirus. This virus is typically transmitted via respiratory droplets and primarily causes a mild infection characterized by a rash, low fever, and swollen glands. However, its most significant health impact occurs when a pregnant woman is infected, particularly in the first trimester, leading to congenital rubella syndrome.

questions.text: A two-year-old boy presents with delayed speech, difficulties in communication, and repetitive behaviors such as staring at his own hands. He struggles with making friends and concentrating. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Autism

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests Autism (now classified as Autism Spectrum Disorder in current diagnostic systems). The key features presented in this case include:

  1. Delayed speech and difficulties in communication (language impairment)
  2. Repetitive behaviors (staring at hands) which represent restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior
  3. Social interaction difficulties (struggles with making friends)
  4. Age of presentation before 3 years (the child is 2 years old)

 

These symptoms align perfectly with the core diagnostic criteria of autism, which includes impairments in social interaction, and restricted/repetitive behaviors. Communication deficits are also often seen in autism.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. ADHD (Incorrect): While ADHD can present with concentration difficulties, it typically doesn't include speech delays, repetitive behaviors, or social interaction difficulties as primary symptoms. ADHD is characterized primarily by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. 
  • Option C. Mental Retardation (Incorrect): Now termed Intellectual Disability, this condition involves below-average intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior. While intellectual disability can co-occur with autism (around 30% of cases), the repetitive behaviors and specific social interaction difficulties described are more characteristic of autism than isolated intellectual disability.
  • Option D. Specific Learning Disability (Incorrect): Learning disabilities involve difficulties in specific academic skills (reading, writing, mathematics) out of proportion to the intellectual functioning of the child. They aren't typically diagnosed in toddlers as these skills aren't yet expected, and they don't explain the communication deficits, repetitive behaviors, or social difficulties described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autism is characterized by impairments in social interaction, and restricted/repetitive behaviors. Communication deficits are also often present in autism. These symptoms typically manifest before age 3, making early identification possible.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male smoker presents with a history of progressive dyspnea and chronic cough. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) reveal the following: (FMGE JAN 2025)

 

  • Decreased FEV₁
  • Decreased FEV₁/FVC ratio (<70%)
  • Minimal improvement in FEV₁ after bronchodilator therapy

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

 

Explanation:

 

This case presents a classic presentation of COPD with the following diagnostic features:

 

  • History of smoking (major risk factor)
  • Progressive dyspnea and chronic cough (typical symptoms)
  • PFT findings:
    • Decreased FEV₁ and FEV₁/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic of obstructive airway disease)
    • Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response (distinguishing it from asthma, which shows significant bronchodilator response)

 

According to the GOLD criteria, a post-bronchodilator FEV₁/FVC ratio <70% confirms COPD in patients with appropriate symptoms and risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Incorrect

 

  • Shows a restrictive pattern on PFTs with FEV₁/FVC >70% and reduced total lung capacity (TLC)

 

Option C. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): Incorrect

 

  • ILD also shows a restrictive pattern, not obstruction
  • Would present with decreased lung volumes and preserved FEV₁/FVC ratio

 

Option D. Asthma: Incorrect

 

  • Asthma can show decreased FEV₁ and FEV₁/FVC ratio, but it typically demonstrates significant bronchodilator reversibility (>12% and >200 mL improvement in FEV₁), which is not seen in this case

 

Educational Objective:

 

COPD is diagnosed by a post-bronchodilator FEV₁/FVC ratio <70%, minimal bronchodilator response, and risk factors such as smoking.

questions.text: A tall 10-year-old boy presents with Sexual Maturity Rating 5 and hyperpigmentation. His BP is 150/100 mm Hg. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

 

The presentation of a tall 10-year-old boy with a Sexual Maturity Rating (SMR) of 5 and hypertension (BP 150/100 mm Hg) indicates precocious puberty. The SMR of 5 typically signifies full sexual maturity, which is unusual for a 10-year-old and suggests precocious puberty.

 

Hyperpigmentation is likely due to elevated ACTH levels, which can occur in congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The key to the diagnosis is understanding the enzyme deficiencies that lead to CAH and their associated symptoms.

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency leads to increased production of 11-deoxycorticosterone, a mineralocorticoid that causes hypertension due to salt retention. This condition also results in excess androgen production, leading to precocious puberty in boys and virilization in girls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 21β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This is the most common cause of CAH but is typically associated with salt-wasting, not hypertension. It results in increased androgen production leading to virilization and ambiguous genitalia in females, and precocious puberty in males.

 

Option C. 17β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This deficiency is characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia but does not usually cause hyperpigmentation or precocious puberty. It often results in underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option D. SCC (side-chain cleavage) deficiency: This enzyme deficiency leads to a severe form of CAH with salt-wasting and adrenal insufficiency but is not typically associated with hypertension or hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency in congenital adrenal hyperplasia causes hypertension due to salt retention and precocious puberty due to excess androgen production.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for sample collection in a tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride + Potassium dichromate

 

Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) can be measured through various methods, including gas chromatography. For accurate measurement of BAC, the blood sample is typically collected in a gray-top vial. This vial contains a mixture of sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate.

 

Sodium fluoride acts as a preservative and prevents glycolysis, which could otherwise lower the concentration of alcohol in the blood sample.

 

However, when using the potassium dichromate test for BAC, potassium dichromate is included in the sample collection tube. In this test, potassium dichromate, which is orange in color, reacts with ethanol present in the blood sample. This reaction converts ethanol to acetic acid and simultaneously reduces potassium dichromate to chromium, which turns the solution green. The intensity of the green color directly correlates with the alcohol concentration in the sample, providing a visual indication of BAC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin + EDTA: This combination is generally used as an anticoagulant in blood samples for various laboratory tests but is not specifically used for BAC measurement.

 

Option C. Heparin: While heparin is an anticoagulant, it is not used in the collection tubes for blood alcohol concentration testing.

 

Option D. Sodium citrate: Sodium citrate is also an anticoagulant, commonly used in coagulation studies, but it is not relevant for BAC measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride and potassium dichromate are the substances used in the tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement. Potassium dichromate reacts with ethanol in the blood sample, facilitating the detection and quantification of alcohol concentration

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the X-ray? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patella fracture

 

The X-ray provided shows a clear fracture line through the patella, indicating a patella fracture.

 

In the provided image, the presence of a sharp, discontinuous line through the patella confirms the diagnosis of a patella fracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemarthrosis: This condition would cause swelling in the joint but would not show a fracture line. The X-ray does not indicate swelling without a fracture, ruling out hemarthrosis.

 

 

Option C. Bipartite patella: This is a congenital condition where the patella is naturally in two parts. It shows smooth, well-defined borders unlike the jagged edges seen in fractures. The X-ray here clearly shows a fracture line, not a bipartite patella.

 

 

Option D. Ligament injury: Ligament injuries do not show up on X-rays as they involve soft tissues. Thus, this option is not relevant to the findings on the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A patella fracture can be identified on an X-ray by a distinct fracture line through the patella, differentiating it from other conditions like hemarthrosis, bipartite patella, and ligament injuries.

questions.text: Which channel opens when action potential begins? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Na+ influx

 

The initiation of an action potential in a neuron begins with the opening of voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels. When a neuron receives a sufficient threshold stimulus, these sodium channels open, allowing Na+ ions to flow into the cell. This influx of positive sodium ions causes the membrane potential to become more positive, a process known as depolarization.

 

Depolarization is the first phase of the action potential, which is essential for the propagation of electrical signals along the neuron. Following depolarization, the action potential continues with other ion movements that facilitate the signal's transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cl- influx: Chloride ions typically move into the cell during inhibitory postsynaptic potentials, causing hyperpolarization (making the inside of the cell more negative). This is not related to the initiation of action potentials.

 

Option C. K+ efflux: Potassium efflux occurs during the repolarization phase of the action potential, not at the beginning. Repolarization helps restore the resting membrane potential after depolarization.

 

Option D. Ca2+ influx: Calcium influx is crucial in various cellular processes, such as neurotransmitter release at synapses. However, it is not involved in the initial depolarization phase of the action potential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initiation of an action potential in a neuron is marked by the opening of voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels, leading to Na+ influx and membrane depolarization.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about Alagille Syndrome? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Peroxisomal biogenesis disorder

 

Alagille syndrome is not a peroxisomal biogenesis disorder. It is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in JAG1 gene that affects multiple organ systems including the liver, heart, eyes, and skeleton. The syndrome is characterized by bile duct paucity leading to cholestatic jaundice, butterfly vertebrae, characteristic facial features (including prominent forehead, deep-set eyes, and pointed chin), and cardiac anomalies, particularly right-sided cardiac defects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous xanthoma - This is actually a true feature of Alagille syndrome. Patients often develop xanthomas due to chronic cholestasis and resulting hypercholesterolemia.

 

Option C. Arteriohepatic dysplasia - This is another name for Alagille syndrome, referring to the combination of hepatic and vascular manifestations of the disease, so this statement is true.

 

Option D. Tetralogy of Fallot - This is a true association of Alagille syndrome. Cardiac manifestations are common in Alagille syndrome, with Tetralogy of Fallot and pulmonary artery stenosis being the most frequent cardiac abnormalities seen. Alagille syndrome is associated with "Pulmonary artery stenosis, TOF."

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alagille syndrome is an arterio-hepatic dysplasia characterized by bile duct paucity, butterfly vertebrae, distinctive facial features, and cardiac defects (particularly TOF and pulmonary stenosis), but it is not a peroxisomal biogenesis disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following is not another name for an inverted papilloma of the nose? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Juvenile papilloma

 

Explanation:


Juvenile papilloma is not a recognized alternative name for inverted papilloma of the nose. Inverted papilloma is a distinctive tumor of the nasal cavity that grows in an inverted fashion, with hyperplastic papillomatous tissue growing into the stroma rather than in an exophytic manner. It most commonly arises from the lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transitional cell papilloma: This is a correct alternative name for inverted papilloma. The term relates to the transitional epithelium that lines the tumor.

 

Option B. Ringertz tumor: This is indeed another name for inverted papilloma, named after the pathologist who described its characteristic inverted growth pattern.

 

Option C. Schneiderian papilloma: This is a valid alternative name for inverted papilloma, referring to its origin from the Schneiderian membrane (the non-olfactory mucosa of the nose).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Inverted papilloma is known by several names including transitional cell papilloma, Ringertz tumor, and Schneiderian papilloma, reflecting its histological features and growth pattern, but juvenile papilloma is not among its recognized synonyms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in making a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cognitive dysfunction

 

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is diagnosed based on specific criteria that include impairments in social interaction and communication, as well as restrictive and repetitive patterns of behavior. Abnormalities in social communication and socialization, as well as restricted interests and behaviors, are key components of the diagnostic criteria for ASD. However, cognitive dysfunction, while it may be present in some individuals with ASD, is not a primary criterion used to diagnose the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormalities in social communication: This statement is correct. Impaired social communication is a core feature of ASD and is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option B. Abnormalities in socialisation: This statement is correct. Difficulties in socialization, which include challenges in social interaction, are also part of the diagnostic criteria for ASD.

 

Option C. Restriction in interests and behaviour: This statement is correct. Restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior and interests are essential criteria for diagnosing ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder includes impairments in social interaction, social communication, and restrictive, repetitive behaviors, but not cognitive dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used to prevent painful vaso-occlusive crises and decrease long-term complications in sickle cell anemia? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydroxyurea.

 

Hydroxyurea is widely used in the management of sickle cell anemia. It helps to increase the concentration of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in the bloodstream, which is less likely to participate in the sickling process that characterizes sickle cell disease. By reducing the sickling of red blood cells, hydroxyurea lowers the incidence of vaso-occlusive crises that cause pain and can lead to organ damage. Additionally, the drug has been shown to have a positive impact on the long-term complications associated with sickle cell anemia, including reducing the risk of stroke and other serious events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methotrexate plus leucovorin: This combination is not used for sickle cell anemia. Methotrexate is primarily used in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases, and leucovorin is given to mitigate the side effects of methotrexate.

 

Option C. Methionine: Methionine is an essential amino acid that is not used to treat sickle cell anemia or its complications. It has no role in preventing vaso-occlusive crises. Rather L-glutamine is the amino acid that is used in sickle cell disease.

 

Option D. Eltrombopag: Eltrombopag is a medication that stimulates platelet production and is used in conditions like chronic immune thrombocytopenia. It is not indicated for the treatment or prevention of complications in sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydroxyurea is the primary medication used to prevent painful vaso-occlusive crises and decrease long-term complications in sickle cell anemia by increasing the concentration of fetal hemoglobin (HbF).

questions.text: After parotidectomy, lower lip paralysis was seen in a patient. Which of the following part of facial nerve was involved ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

The cervical branch of the facial nerve is responsible for innervating the platysma muscle, which is crucial for controlling lower lip movements. During a parotidectomy, if this branch is damaged, it can lead to paralysis of the lower lip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid duct: The parotid duct is not a part of the facial nerve. It is a salivary duct and does not contribute to nerve innervation.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead, including the frontalis, corrugator supercilii, and orbicularis oculi. It does not affect lower lip movements.

 

Option D. Main trunk of facial nerve: The main trunk of the facial nerve divides into several branches, including the temporal and cervical branches. It is not directly responsible for the lower lip movement, as it provides the general innervation before splitting into specific branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the cervical branch of the facial nerve during a parotidectomy can result in lower lip paralysis.

questions.text: Which phenomenon describes vertigo induced by loud sounds? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tullio Phenomenon

 

Explanation:

 

Tullio phenomenon refers to the development of vertigo and nystagmus in response to loud sounds. This occurs due to a pathological connection between the sound-conducting system and the vestibular apparatus. Loud sounds cause abnormal stimulation of the vestibular system, resulting in vestibular symptoms. This phenomenon is seen in conditions like superior semicircular canal dehiscence, perilymphatic fistula, and advanced otosyphilis where there is an abnormal communication between the inner ear fluid compartments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hennebert's Sign: This refers to the development of vertigo and nystagmus on applying pressure to the external auditory canal (positive fistula test) in the absence of a demonstrable fistula (false positive). It is typically seen in congenital syphilis due to the presence of fibrous adhesions between the stapes footplate and the membranous labyrinth. Unlike Tullio phenomenon which is triggered by sound, Hennebert's sign is elicited by pressure changes.

 

Option C. Roll-over Phenomenon: This is seen in retrocochlear hearing loss (e.g., acoustic neuroma). It refers to a decrease in speech discrimination scores as the intensity of sound is increased beyond a certain level. Unlike Tullio phenomenon, it does not involve vertigo and is related to hearing discrimination rather than vestibular function.

 

Option D. Recruitment Phenomenon: This is the abnormal growth of loudness perception seen in cochlear hearing loss. Patients with cochlear lesions have difficulty hearing soft sounds, but as intensity increases, they perceive loudness as rapidly growing to normal or even uncomfortable levels. This phenomenon affects hearing rather than balance and does not cause vertigo.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Tullio phenomenon specifically describes the vestibular symptoms (vertigo and nystagmus) induced by loud sounds due to pathological communication between the sound-conducting and vestibular systems of the inner ear.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

 

Explanation:

 

A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke's pouch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.

 

 

Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.

 

 

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngioma should be considered in pediatric patients presenting with visual disturbances and evidence of a calcified mass in the suprasellar region on imaging. This diagnosis is important due to the potential impact on the optic pathways and pituitary gland function, requiring careful management.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations are seen in Vitamin A deficiency? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bitot’s spots

 

Vitamin A deficiency can lead to several ocular manifestations due to its crucial role in maintaining healthy epithelial tissues and vision. Bitot’s spots are one of the characteristic signs of Vitamin A deficiency. These spots are foamy, whitish accumulations on the conjunctiva, typically on the temporal side. They result from the keratinization of the conjunctiva and are a sign of advanced Vitamin A deficiency, often seen alongside other symptoms like night blindness and xerosis.

 

 

 

 

Vitamin A toxicity – Main clinical feature is raised ICT (Intracranial tension) resembling Brain tumor also known as Pseudo tumor cerebri.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vogts stria: Vogts stria are fine, radial lines seen in the iris of some individuals. They are not associated with Vitamin A deficiency but are instead related to the normal structure of the eye or sometimes linked to specific eye conditions like keratoconus.

 

Option C. Arlts line: Arlts line refers to a horizontal line on the upper tarsal conjunctiva that can appear in chronic trachoma. This condition is not related to Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Harnor tantra dots: This is not a recognized medical term and does not relate to any known manifestations of Vitamin A deficiency or other ocular conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot’s spots are a classic ocular manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency, often appearing as foamy, whitish patches on the conjunctiva.

questions.text: What is the typical sequence of color changes observed in a common superficial bruise? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (Red-Blue-Brown-Green-Yellow-Normal).

 

Explanation:

 

The color changes in a bruise follow a predictable sequence as the hemoglobin in the extravasated blood undergoes degradation. Initially, the bruise appears red due to the presence of oxygenated hemoglobin. Within a few hours to 3 days, it turns blue due to deoxygenated hemoglobin. By the 4th-5th day, the bruise appears bluish-black to brown as hemosiderin (an iron-storage complex) forms. Around the 5th-6th day, the bruise turns green due to the formation of biliverdin (a green pigment formed during hemoglobin breakdown). Finally, between the 7th-14th day, the bruise turns yellow due to bilirubin formation. After about 2 weeks, the bruise disappears as the normal skin color returns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Red-Blue-Green-Brown-Yellow-Normal - This sequence is incorrect because brown (hemosiderin) precedes green (biliverdin) in the degradation process.

 

Option C. Red-Blue-Brown-Yellow-Green-Normal - This sequence is incorrect because green (biliverdin) precedes yellow (bilirubin) in the hemoglobin breakdown pathway.

 

Option D. Red-Yellow-Blue-Brown-Green-Normal - This sequence is entirely incorrect as yellow appears much later in the bruise evolution, not early.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The color change sequence in a bruise follows the biochemical degradation of hemoglobin: red (oxygenated blood) → blue (deoxygenated hemoglobin) → brown (hemosiderin) → green (biliverdin) → yellow (bilirubin) → normal skin color.

questions.text: Which of the following is the pattern of inheritance with the pedigree chart provided in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial inheritance

 

The pedigree chart provided in the image demonstrates a pattern of inheritance where an affected female passes the trait or disease to all of her offspring, regardless of their gender. Additionally, the affected males do not pass the trait to any of their offspring. This pattern is characteristic of mitochondrial inheritance, also known as maternal inheritance.

 

Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited exclusively from the mother because mitochondria in the sperm are typically not involved in fertilization. Therefore, any mutations in mitochondrial DNA will be passed from an affected mother to all of her children. However, because males do not contribute mitochondria to their offspring, they do not pass on mitochondrial diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal recessive: Autosomal recessive inheritance typically requires both parents to carry one copy of the mutated gene, and it affects both males and females equally. The pattern in the pedigree, where all children of an affected female are affected, does not fit an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Option B. Autosomal dominant: Autosomal dominant inheritance usually involves a 50% chance of passing the mutated gene from an affected parent to each child, regardless of gender. The pedigree showing all offspring of an affected female being affected, while none of the offspring of an affected male are affected, does not fit this pattern.

 

Option C. X-linked recessive: X-linked recessive inheritance usually affects males more frequently, as they have only one X chromosome. Affected males would pass the mutated gene to all of their daughters (who would be carriers) but none of their sons. This pattern does not match the pedigree chart provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by the transmission of a trait from an affected mother to all of her offspring, while affected males do not pass the trait to their children. This unique pattern is due to the inheritance of mitochondrial DNA, which is maternally inherited.

 

Example of Maternal/ mitochondrial inheritance diseases: Leber's Optic Neuropathy, MELAS Syndrome (Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like manifestation).

questions.text: For ASHA worker in an urban area, what is the recommended population norm? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1000-2500

 

In urban areas, USHA (Urban Social Health Activist) worker, which is equivalent to ASHA worker in rural areas, is deployed under the National Urban Health Mission (NUHM) launched in 2013. The recommended population norm for USHA worker is 1 per 1000-2500 population. This is different from rural ASHA workers who have a population norm of 2 per 1000.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Population norm for USHA (Urban Social Health Activist) worker under NUHM is 1 per 1000-2500 population.

questions.text: The mosaic pattern of cement lines is characteristically seen in which condition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Paget's disease of bone

 

  • The mosaic pattern of cement lines is the diagnostic histological feature of Paget's disease of bone (also called Osteitis Deformans). 

 

 

  • This characteristic pattern results from excessive disorganized bone turnover due to osteoclast defect, where osteoclasts become larger and irregular. 
  • There's an initial phase of excessive bone resorption (osteoclastic activity) followed by a compensatory phase of abnormal, rapid, and disorganized bone formation (osteoblastic activity).
  • This disordered remodeling creates a distinctive puzzle-like or "mosaic" appearance of the cement lines between bone lamellae that is pathognomonic for Paget's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: Hyperthyroidism causes increased bone turnover and can lead to osteopenia or osteoporosis, but it does not produce the characteristic mosaic pattern of cement lines. It typically shows increased osteoclastic activity without the disordered remodeling seen in Paget's disease.

 

 

Option C. Renal osteodystrophy: Renal osteodystrophy presents with a mixture of features including those of hyperparathyroidism, osteomalacia, osteoporosis, and osteosclerosis. It can produce "rugger jersey spine" appearance, but does not show the mosaic pattern of cement lines characteristic of Paget's disease.

 

 

Option D. Osteomalacia: Osteomalacia is characterized by inadequate mineralization of osteoid tissue resulting in excessive uncalcified osteoid seams on histology. It does not display the mosaic cement line pattern seen in Paget's disease.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The mosaic (or marble) pattern of cement lines is a pathognomonic histological feature of Paget's disease, reflecting the excessive disorganized bone turnover that characterizes this condition.

choices.text: Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea
Christmas tree pattern - Lichen planus

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

Option A.

 

Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

  • Given clinical scenario and images showing Collarette scale (Herald patch) and Christmas tree pattern distributed lesions, points to a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

 

Pityriasis Rosea:

 

  • This is a common skin condition characterized by a herald patch, followed by a distinctive, symmetric rash in a Christmas tree pattern.
  • It primarily affects the back and trunk. The rash is often accompanied by a Collarette scale, where the scale is more prominent at the periphery of the lesion.

 

Christmas Tree Pattern:

 

  • The symmetric distribution and orientation of lesions along the lines of skin cleavage on the back is a hallmark of pityriasis rosea.

 

PITYRIASIS ROSEA

 

  • Acute: Self-limiting (6-12 weeks) disease.
  • Etiology: Most common viral trigger is HHV 7.
  • Asymptomatic >> mild pruritus may be present.
  • Features:
    • 1st lesion: Herald patch / mother patch 1-2 weeks later.
    • Secondary lesions: Scaly papules → oval annular plaques → mild pigmentary changes → fades slowly in 6-12 weeks.
  • Distribution of Lesions: Christmas tree pattern (Downwards & outwards from the spine along the lines of Langer).
  • Treatment: Counsel, self-limiting 6-12 weeks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Wickham’s Striae - Lichen Planus:

 

  • Wickham's striae are fine, white lines found on the surface of papules in lichen planus.
  • Surface of lichen planus lesions seen with oil on top of lesion reveals these whitish linear streaks.

 

 

  • Lichen planus typically presents with pruritic, purplish, polygonal papules and does not exhibit a Christmas tree pattern.

 

Option C. Christmas Tree Pattern - Lichen Planus:

 

This is incorrect because, although lichen planus is a common dermatologic condition, it does not present with a Christmas tree pattern. This pattern is specific to pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D. Woronoff Ring – Seborrheic Dermatitis:

 

  • The Woronoff ring is a hypopigmented ring surrounding individual psoriatic lesions. It is usually associated with treatment, most commonly UV radiation or topical steroids.

 

 

  • Seborrheic dermatitis presents with greasy, scaly lesions predominantly on the scalp, face, and upper trunk.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When presented with symmetrically distributed, asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on the back in a young adult, consider pityriasis rosea, particularly if the lesions follow a Christmas tree pattern.
  • This pattern, along with the presence of collarette scaling, is highly suggestive of pityriasis rosea.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page 35.8, 37.3, 115.9

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate show the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?(NEET  PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical vignette of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance points to diagnosis of Gaucher's disease, in which enzyme deficient is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher’s Disease

choices.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented with hearing loss. On PTA, the amount of hearing loss was 56dB: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

 

Otosclerosis is a common cause of progressive hearing loss, particularly in young adults and often worsens during pregnancy due to hormonal changes. The condition is characterized by abnormal bone growth around the stapes bone in the middle ear, leading to its fixation. This fixation prevents the stapes from vibrating in response to sound waves, thereby reducing the transmission of sound to the inner ear and causing hearing loss.

 

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane (eardrum) typically appears normal upon examination. The hearing loss in otosclerosis is conductive, meaning it is due to a problem in the outer or middle ear, which transmits sound to the inner ear. A pure-tone audiogram (PTA) showing a 56dB hearing loss indicates significant conductive hearing impairment, consistent with otosclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane: This condition is not typical of otosclerosis. Ossicular fixation in otosclerosis occurs with an intact tympanic membrane. A non-intact tympanic membrane would suggest a different pathology, such as chronic otitis media.

 

Option C. Erosion with intact tympanic membrane: Ossicular erosion with an intact tympanic membrane is not characteristic of otosclerosis. Ossicular erosion is more commonly seen in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), particularly in its cholesteatoma form, which can erode the ossicles but usually involves perforation of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. Erosion without intact tympanic membrane: This is also not typical of otosclerosis. Erosion without an intact tympanic membrane again points towards chronic otitis media, especially with complications leading to ossicular erosion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otosclerosis often presents as progressive conductive hearing loss with an intact tympanic membrane, and the hearing loss can worsen during pregnancy. The classic finding is ossicular fixation, particularly of the stapes bone.

choices.text: The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium
It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots
This rule involves the observation of fracture lines
It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously

questions.text: Regarding Puppe's rule, all of the following statements are true EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously.

 

Explanation: 

 

Puppe's rule states that when two fracture lines intersect each other, the second fracture line never crosses the first one. This principle is crucial for determining the sequence of impacts in cases of multiple skull fractures. The rule specifically helps in establishing chronology - which impact occurred first and which occurred subsequently. For this rule to be applicable, the fractures must have occurred at different times, not simultaneously. This makes option D incorrect because Puppe's rule has no value in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously, as the rule is specifically designed to determine sequence over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium - This is true. Puppe's rule is applied in cases of cranial fractures, including those caused by bullet injuries, to determine the sequence of impacts.

 

Option B. It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots - This is true. The primary purpose of Puppe's rule is to determine the sequence of impacts when multiple fractures are present.

 

Option C. This rule involves the observation of fracture lines - This is true. Puppe's rule is based on observing how fracture lines intersect each other. The second fracture line stops at or is deflected by the first fracture line.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Puppe's rule is a forensic principle that helps determine the sequence of multiple impacts to the skull by analyzing how fracture lines intersect, but it has no value in cases where injuries occur simultaneously.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy from Kerala presents with fever, headache, and drowsiness. His family reports that he has consumed palm fruit recently. Which virus is considered in the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah

 

Explanation

 

The presentation of fever, headache, and drowsiness in a boy from Kerala who has recently consumed palm fruit, a known vector for bat-related transmissions, suggests Nipah virus infection. Nipah virus is known for causing severe encephalitis and has been associated with outbreaks in Kerala, often linked to bat consumption of fruits and subsequent transmission to humans.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Dengue: Does not typically cause encephalitis, although severe dengue can lead to altered sensorium.

 

Option C. Ebola: Not endemic in India and typically presents with hemorrhagic symptoms.

 

Option D. Chikungunya: Causes fever and arthritis, not encephalitis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Nipah virus should be considered in cases of encephalitis, especially in regions like Kerala, where outbreaks linked to bat consumption of palm fruit have been reported.

questions.text: Features of MEN2B are all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parathyroid hyperplasia

 

MEN2B syndrome is characterized by a distinct set of clinical features known as the "4 M's":

 

  1. Marfanoid body habitus
  2. Mucosal neuromas
  3. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  4. Megacolon (Hirschsprung disease)

 

Additionally, pheochromocytoma is also a feature of MEN2B. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene located on chromosome 10.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hyperplasia is NOT a component of MEN2B syndrome, while the characteristic features include medullary thyroid carcinoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and megacolon (the 4 M's).

questions.text: A 4-week-old child was brought to the emergency with recurrent episodes of non-bilious vomiting. He was dehydrated. What should be corrected before performing surgical treatment in this baby? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia

 

The child presents with recurrent non-bilious vomiting, which is a classic sign of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). IHPS is a condition in infants causing severe vomiting due to the thickening of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction.

 

Patients with IHPS often develop a specific electrolyte imbalance characterized by hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. The vomiting leads to a loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid), resulting in low chloride levels and secondary metabolic alkalosis. This condition also results in potassium loss, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Before performing surgical treatment (such as a pyloromyotomy, often referenced in this context as the Ramstedt procedure), it is crucial to correct the electrolyte imbalance to stabilize the patient. The primary focus is on correcting hypokalemia because potassium is essential for normal cellular function and cardiac rhythm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: This condition involves high potassium levels, which is not typically seen in patients with IHPS. Instead, these patients usually have low potassium levels due to vomiting.

 

Option C. Hyponatremia: While hyponatremia (low sodium levels) can occur, it is generally not as significant or immediately life-threatening as hypokalemia in the context of IHPS.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels are not characteristic of IHPS. The vomiting associated with IHPS more commonly leads to losses of electrolytes like potassium and chloride, not an increase in sodium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is often associated with hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Correction of hypokalemia is essential before surgical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is useful for a patient having Haemophilia B?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fresh frozen plasma

 

Haemophilia B is characterized by a deficiency in factor IX. The treatment for haemophilia B focuses on supplementing the deficient factor IX. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is an excellent source of factor IX and is therefore useful in treating haemophilia B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoprecipitate: Incorrect. Cryoprecipitate is rich in factor VIII and is primarily used for treating haemophilia A, not haemophilia B.

 

Option C. Recombinant factor 8: Incorrect. Recombinant factor VIII is used to treat haemophilia A, which is a deficiency in factor VIII, not factor IX.

 

Option D. Cryo poor plasma: Incorrect. Although cryo poor plasma can still contain some factor IX, it is not the best choice compared to fresh frozen plasma. Cryo poor plasma is more commonly used for treating thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia B is a genetic deficiency of Factor IX, also called Christmas disease.

 

It is an X-linked recessive bleeding disorder, causing:

 

  • Easy bruising
  • Hemarthroses
  • Prolonged bleeding after injury or surgery

 

For the treatment of haemophilia B, fresh frozen plasma is an effective source of factor IX. Recombinant factor IX would be the best treatment option if available.

choices.text: It moves against the concentration gradient

questions.text: Which statement is true about facilitated diffusion? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. It requires a carrier

 

Explanation:

 

Facilitated diffusion is a form of passive transport that requires specific carrier proteins to move substances across the cell membrane. These carrier proteins bind molecules and then change their configuration, facilitating the movement of the bound substance across the membrane. This type of transport is characterized by several key properties: it requires specific carrier proteins, exhibits saturation kinetics, shows specificity for the transported substance, and can demonstrate competition between similar molecules for the same carrier.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. It is active - False. Facilitated diffusion is classified as passive transport, not active transport. It moves substances down their concentration or electrical gradient without requiring energy input.
  • Option c. It requires ATP - False. Unlike primary active transport, facilitated diffusion does not require ATP or other energy sources. The movement occurs due to the existing concentration gradient.
  • Option d. It moves against the concentration gradient - False. Facilitated diffusion only moves substances down their concentration gradient (from high to low concentration), never against it. Moving substances against their concentration gradient requires active transport mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Facilitated diffusion is a passive transport process requiring specific carrier proteins (such as GLUT for glucose) that enables the movement of substances down their concentration gradient across cell membranes at a faster rate than would occur by simple diffusion alone.

questions.text: Match the Dermatological disorders in Column A with their respective investigations in Column B: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

 

Explanation:

 

Correct matches:

 

 

1. Tinea: Tinea infections, also known as dermatophytosis, are fungal infections of the skin, hair, or nails. The diagnosis is commonly made by performing a potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount of skin scrapings, which reveals fungal hyphae under a microscope.

 

2. Lepromatous leprosy: This form of leprosy is diagnosed using a slit skin smear, where a sample from the skin lesion is stained and examined for the presence of acid-fast bacilli (Mycobacterium leprae).

 

 

3. Lupus vulgaris: Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis. The diagnosis often involves a biopsy of the lesion, which shows granulomatous inflammation with caseation necrosis and the presence of acid-fast bacilli.

 

4. Allergic dermatitis: Allergic contact dermatitis is diagnosed using a patch test, where suspected allergens are applied to the skin under occlusive patches to observe for a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea is diagnosed with a KOH mount, lepromatous leprosy with a slit skin smear, lupus vulgaris with a biopsy, and allergic dermatitis with a patch test.

questions.text: Desert rheumatism is caused by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coccidioides immitis


Desert rheumatism, also known as Valley fever or California fever, is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis. This fungus is commonly found in desert regions, such as the southwestern United States, including California and Arizona. The disease is contracted by inhaling airborne fungal spores, which can cause symptoms ranging from mild flu-like conditions to severe pulmonary or disseminated infections. The mnemonic "Desert, Valley, Cali" helps remember the association with desert rheumatism, Valley fever, and California fever, all linked to Coccidioides immitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis: This condition is caused by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, which is commonly found in bird and bat droppings, particularly in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. It does not cause desert rheumatism.

 

Option C. Mucormycosis: This is an infection caused by molds from the Mucorales order, which typically affects immunocompromised individuals. It is not associated with desert rheumatism.

 

Option D. Paracoccidioidomycosis: This disease is caused by the fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and occurs predominantly in South America. It is unrelated to desert rheumatism.

 

Educational Objective:


Desert rheumatism (Valley fever or California fever) is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about protein kinase? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. All of the above

 

Explanation:


Protein kinases are regulatory enzymes that add phosphate groups to substrate proteins, modifying their function. They possess all the characteristics listed in the options. Protein kinases can phosphorylate threonine residues (along with serine and tyrosine residues) depending on the specific kinase family. Many are involved in the IP3-DAG signaling pathway, particularly protein kinase C (PKC) which is directly activated by DAG. Additionally, several protein kinases are activated by calcium, including the calcium-calmodulin-dependent protein kinases (CaMKs).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Phosphorylates threonine residue: This statement alone is correct but incomplete. Protein kinases can indeed phosphorylate threonine residues, but this is just one of their many characteristics.
  • Option b. Involved in IP3–DAG mechanism: This statement is also correct but incomplete. Protein kinase C is specifically activated as part of the IP3-DAG signaling pathway.
  • Option c. Activated by Ca2+: This statement is correct but incomplete. Several protein kinases, particularly the CaMK family, are activated by calcium, often through the calcium-binding protein calmodulin.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Protein kinases serve as critical effectors in cellular signaling pathways by phosphorylating substrate proteins at specific amino acid residues (serine, threonine, or tyrosine), and their activity can be regulated through multiple mechanisms including second messengers such as DAG and calcium.

questions.text: Which is the most common Osteoporotic fracture site?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertebral fracture

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • The fractures that are most common (in decreasing order) are vertebral fracture > hip (neck femur) > lower end radius.
  • Most of the vertebral fractures are asymptomatic and are identified incidentally during radiograph for other purpose.
  • Few of these present as backache of varying degree.
  • Up to 70 years of age, the order of fracture incidence is vertebral > Colle’s.
  • Overall and in > 70 years of age, it is vertebral > Hip > Colle’s.
  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse), codfish appearance and pencilling of vertebrae.

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra (Biconcave vertebra)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intertrochanteric fracture: These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. These patients are also typically older than patients who suffer femoral neck fractures. In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism. The femur is the second most common site of fracture in the osteoporotic patients.

 

Option C. Femoral shaft fracture: Femoral shaft fractures can result from high or low energy mechanisms. The most common causes include automobile accidents, falls from heights, ground-level falls in individuals with osteoporosis, and gunshots. About 75% fractures are caused by high energy mechanisms. Other less common causes are atypical fractures from bisphosphonate use, pathologic fractures through a bone lesion, insufficiency fractures from osteoporosis, and stress fractures from overuse in athletes.

 

Option D. Subtrochanteric fracture: Subtrochanteric fractures are mainly seen in 2 patient populations: spiral fractures in osteoporotic patients and atypical insufficiency fractures that happen after no to low-energy trauma (e.g., patients who use long-term bisphosphate therapy). But femur involvement is the second common site in osteoporosis for fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site for osteoporotic fractures is the vertebral column followed by femur (mainly neck) and lower end of the radius.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the auditory pathway? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Genu of the internal capsule

 

The auditory pathway consists of multiple relays from the cochlea to the auditory cortex. The trapezoid body contains crossing fibers from the cochlear nuclei to the superior olivary nucleus. The lateral lemniscus carries auditory information from the superior olivary nucleus to the inferior colliculus. The medial geniculate body is the thalamic relay nucleus for auditory information before it reaches the auditory cortex. However, the genu of internal capsule contains corticobulbar fibers and not auditory fibers. Auditory radiations pass through the sublentiform part of the internal capsule, not the genu.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trapezoid body - This is part of the auditory pathway, containing crossing fibers from cochlear nuclei to superior olivary nucleus.

 

Option B. Medial geniculate body - This is a key relay station in the auditory pathway, located in the thalamus. It receives input from the inferior colliculus and projects to the auditory cortex.

 

Option D. Lateral lemniscus - This is an important auditory tract in the brainstem that carries information from the superior olivary nucleus to the inferior colliculus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The auditory pathway involves the trapezoid body, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, and medial geniculate body before reaching the auditory cortex via the sublentiform (not genu) part of the internal capsule.

questions.text: What is the observational unit in ecological investigations? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Population

 

  • In ecological studies, the unit of observation is the population or community, which refers to a group of individuals or entities living in the same geographic area or sharing a common characteristic.
  • Ecological studies are observational studies that investigate the relationship between exposure and disease at a population level rather than an individual level.
  • Therefore, the data collected and analyzed in ecological studies are not at the individual level, but at the group or population level.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from the nose, nasal obstruction and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image what would be the diagnosis of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by the aquatic organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It primarily affects mucous membranes, especially in the nasal passages but also the eyes, ears, and occasionally other areas. Patients typically present with polypoidal masses in the nasal area that can cause bleeding, nasal obstruction, and respiratory difficulty. It is commonly associated with exposure to stagnant water.

Histopathology: Characteristic findings include large, thick-walled sporangia containing numerous endospores, as observed in the provided histopathological image.

Other Options: 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that commonly appears on sun-exposed areas but can occasionally occur near the nasal region. It typically presents as a nodular lesion with a pearly edge and may have telangiectasias but lacks the distinct histopathology of sporangia with endospores.

Histopathology: Microscopically, it shows nests of basaloid cells with palisading nuclei at the periphery.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the respiratory tract. It leads to the formation of hard, sclerotic nodules and masses mainly in the nasal passages.

Histopathology: It is characterized by the presence of Mikulicz cells, which are large foam cells containing the bacteria, and a background of chronic inflammatory cells.

Option D. Lupus Vulgaris

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting typically on the skin with reddish-brown nodules and plaques that can ulcerate over time. It rarely affects the nasal area directly unless there is disseminated cutaneous involvement.

Histopathology: Shows granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis typical of tuberculosis.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients with nasal masses who have a history of contact with stagnant water bodies, presenting with the characteristic polypoidal mass and sporangia on histopathology.

questions.text: Position of limb in posterior dislocation of shoulder: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Adducted and internally rotated

 

In posterior dislocation of the shoulder, the limb is characteristically held adducted and internally rotated. This position occurs because the humeral head has dislocated posteriorly behind the glenoid. The position is often described as "Up/In" (arm is adducted) in contrast to anterior dislocation where the position is "Down/Out" (arm is abducted). Posterior dislocations are uncommon compared to anterior dislocations and are often caused by electric shock, epilepsy, or a direct blow to the front of the shoulder.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adducted and externally rotated: This position is not seen in shoulder dislocations because external rotation would typically reduce a posterior dislocation. External rotation moves the humeral head anteriorly.

 

Option B. Abducted and externally rotated: This describes the position commonly seen in anterior dislocation of the shoulder, not posterior dislocation. In anterior dislocation, the arm appears "down and out" with the humeral head displaced anteriorly.

 

Option C. Abducted and internally rotated: This is incorrect, as the arm is adducted in a posterior dislocation. While internal rotation is correct for a posterior dislocation, the combination with abduction is not typical.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Posterior dislocation of the shoulder presents with the characteristic "Up/In" position where the arm is adducted and internally rotated, contrasting with the "Down/Out" position (abducted) seen in the more common anterior dislocation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came with early satiety, massive splenomegaly, petechiae, and bleeding gums. Her hemoglobin was 8 gm/dl and TLC was 85,000/mm3. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CML

 

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings are highly suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).

 

The patient, a 20-year-old female, presents with early satiety, which can be attributed to the massive splenomegaly. An enlarged spleen can compress the stomach, leading to a feeling of early satiety. Massive splenomegaly is a characteristic feature of CML, resulting from the infiltration of the spleen by leukemic cells.

 

The presence of petechiae and bleeding gums indicates thrombocytopenia, which is a common finding in CML patients. Thrombocytopenia can be caused by the decreased production of platelets due to the crowding out of normal hematopoietic cells by the leukemic cells in the bone marrow.

 

The patient's hemoglobin level of 8 gm/dl suggests anemia, another common finding in CML. Anemia in CML can be due to the ineffective erythropoiesis caused by the abnormal proliferation of myeloid cells.

 

The most striking finding is the markedly elevated total leukocyte count (TLC) of 85,000/mm3, which is highly indicative of CML. In CML, there is a characteristic uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid cells, leading to a significant increase in the white blood cell count.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia): ALL is more common in pediatric patients and typically presents with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and bone tenderness. The extremely high TLC and massive splenomegaly are more suggestive of CML than ALL.

 

Option B. AML (Acute Myelogenous Leukemia): AML can present with gum hyperplasia, the presence of myeloblasts with granular cytoplasm, or Auer rods (rod-shaped or needle-shaped crystals). The chronic nature of the presentation and the massive splenomegaly are more consistent with CML.

 

 

Option D. CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): CLL is more common in older adults and typically presents with lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and a high lymphocyte count. The high TLC with myeloid predominance and the absence of significant lymphadenopathy make CML a more likely diagnosis than CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) should be strongly suspected in a patient presenting with massive splenomegaly, early satiety, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and a markedly elevated total leukocyte count with myeloid predominance.

 

The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, is the hallmark genetic abnormality in CML.

choices.text: Found in monovalent & pentavalent variant
Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding rotavirus vaccine?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months

 

Rotavirus vaccines are live, attenuated vaccines administered orally to protect against rotavirus infections, which can cause severe diarrhea in infants and young children. The vaccine is available in both monovalent and pentavalent forms.

 

The statement "Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months" is incorrect. The catch-up schedule for the rotavirus vaccine allows for administration up to one year of age. The vaccination schedule generally involves doses at 2 and 4 months of age, with a possible third dose at 6 months depending on the vaccine used. However, the vaccine series should ideally be completed by 8 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Live vaccine: This is true. The rotavirus vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine.

 

Option B. Given orally: This is true. The rotavirus vaccine is administered orally, not by injection.

 

Option C. Found in monovalent & pentavalent variant: This is true. The vaccine is available in both monovalent and pentavalent forms, targeting different strains of the virus.

 

Educational Objective:


The catch-up schedule for the rotavirus vaccine extends up to one year of age, contrary to the incorrect statement that it should not be given after 6 months.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with weight for height less than minus 1 SD & height for age is minus 2 SD. What is the best possible assessment?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic malnutrition

 

Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, is indicated by a height for age that is significantly below the normal. According to World Health Organization (WHO) standards, a height for age that is less than minus 2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population is indicative of stunting. In this question, the child has a height for age of minus 2 SD, which points to chronic malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute malnutrition: This is typically indicated by a significant weight loss over a short period, reflected in weight for height measurements. A weight for height less than minus 3 SD from the median would indicate severe acute malnutrition, but in this case, the weight for height is less than minus 1 SD, which is not sufficient to diagnose acute malnutrition.

 

Option C. Acute on chronic malnutrition: This would be indicated if the child had signs of both chronic malnutrition (height for age less than minus 2 SD) and significant recent weight loss. However, the weight for height is only less than minus 1 SD, not indicative of acute malnutrition.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as chronic malnutrition is clearly indicated by the height for age of minus 2 SD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic malnutrition is diagnosed when a child's height for age is less than minus 2 standard deviations from the median of the reference population, indicating stunting.

questions.text: The most potent natural estrogen is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estradiol

 

Estrogens play a crucial role in the development and regulation of the female reproductive system and secondary sexual characteristics. Among the natural estrogens, estradiol is the most potent. Estradiol is primarily produced by the ovaries and is the predominant estrogen during the reproductive years of a woman. It has the highest affinity for estrogen receptors, making it the most effective at eliciting estrogenic responses in the body.

 

Estrone, on the other hand, is the main estrogen found in postmenopausal women and is less potent than estradiol. Estriol is the weakest of the three natural estrogens and is predominantly produced during pregnancy. Conjugated equine estrogen is a mixture of estrogens derived from the urine of pregnant mares and is less potent than estradiol.

 

Therefore, estradiol is considered the most potent natural estrogen due to its strong affinity for estrogen receptors and its significant role in reproductive physiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrone: Although it is a natural estrogen, estrone is less potent than estradiol. It is primarily found in postmenopausal women and does not exert the same level of estrogenic activity as estradiol.

 

Option C. Estriol: This estrogen is the least potent of the natural estrogens and is mainly produced during pregnancy. It has a much lower affinity for estrogen receptors compared to estradiol.

 

Option D. Conjugated equine estrogen: This is a semi-synthetic mixture of estrogens obtained from horses. While it is used in hormone replacement therapy, its potency is lower than that of estradiol and it is not considered a single natural estrogen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is the most potent natural estrogen, especially during a woman’s reproductive years, due to its high receptor affinity and significant physiological effects

questions.text: Which test is utilized to identify seminal stains? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Barberio's Test

 

Explanation:

 

Explanation: Barberio's test is specifically designed to identify seminal stains. When a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to dried stain extract on a glass slide, it produces yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate. This reaction depends on the presence of spermine from prostatic secretions, making it an effective test for seminal stain identification.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Phenolphthalein Test (Kastle Meyer test) - This is a presumptive test for blood, not semen. It gives a deep permanganate color reaction with blood due to peroxidase activity.

 

Option C. Paraffin Test - This test is not used for seminal stain identification in forensic medicine. It's not included in the standard protocols for testing seminal evidence.

 

Option D. All of the Above - This cannot be correct as only Barberio's test is used for seminal stain identification among the options given.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barberio's test is a confirmatory test for seminal stains that detects spermine (a component of prostate gland) through the formation of distinctive yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate when picric acid is added to the stain.

questions.text: Which posterior mediastinal structure is located posterior and to the right of the esophagus? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Azygos vein

 

The azygos vein is located in the posterior mediastinum, posterior and to the right of the esophagus. In the posterior mediastinum, the azygos vein ascends on the right side of the vertebral column, behind the esophagus, and arches over the root of the right lung to drain into the superior vena cava. The relations of the thoracic part of the esophagus to the right side include the azygos vein, which runs posterior to the esophagus on the right side of the vertebral column.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracic duct - The thoracic duct is located posterior and to the left of the esophagus in the posterior mediastinum, not to the right. It courses upward between the azygos vein and descending aorta.

 

Option B. Descending aorta - The descending thoracic aorta is related to the left side of the esophagus, not the right side. It descends along the left side of the vertebral column.

 

Option D. Vertebral body - While the vertebral column is posterior to the esophagus, it's in the midline rather than specifically to the right of the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The azygos vein runs on the right side of the vertebral column posterior to the esophagus in the posterior mediastinum, making it the only structure among the options that is both posterior and to the right of the esophagus.

questions.text: A 48 year old male smoker presented with cough and foul smelling sputum which increased on change in posture. He had similar episodes multiple times in last few years. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bronchiectasis 

 

Explanation:

 

The key features presented in this case are a 48-year-old male smoker with chronic cough, foul-smelling sputum, and an increase in sputum production upon changing posture. Additionally, the patient has experienced similar episodes multiple times over the past few years. These clinical manifestations strongly suggest a diagnosis of bronchiectasis.

 

Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterized by permanent dilation and destruction of the bronchi (airways) due to recurrent inflammation or infection. It leads to impaired clearance of secretions, resulting in the accumulation of thick, foul-smelling sputum within the dilated airways. The sputum production often increases upon postural changes, as described in this case, due to the pooling of secretions within the dilated bronchial segments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: While asthma can present with cough and wheezing, it is not typically associated with foul-smelling sputum or a significant change in sputum production upon postural changes.

 

Option B. Carcinoma of the lung: Lung cancer can cause cough and sputum production, but the sputum is usually not described as foul-smelling. Additionally, the recurrent nature of the episodes over several years is less consistent with lung cancer.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: A lung abscess can also present with cough and foul-smelling sputum, but it is typically an acute condition and is less likely to have recurrent episodes over several years without appropriate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a history of chronic cough, foul-smelling sputum production that increases with postural changes, and recurrent episodes over several years, bronchiectasis should be strongly considered as the likely diagnosis, especially in the presence of risk factors such as smoking.

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Late distal tubule and collecting duct

questions.text: In a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus, which part of the tubule would have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Late distal tubule and collecting duct

 

In central diabetes insipidus, there is a deficiency of ADH (vasopressin) secretion from the posterior pituitary. Without ADH, the collecting ducts become relatively impermeable to water. This causes the already dilute fluid entering from the distal tubule to remain hypotonic without the normal water reabsorption that would concentrate it. In diabetes insipidus, urine osmolality can be extremely low (50-100 mOsm/L) due to this lack of water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Proximal tubule - Incorrect because proximal tubular fluid remains essentially iso-osmotic with plasma (around 300 mOsm/kg) regardless of ADH status. About 60-70% of filtered water is reabsorbed here through aquaporin-1 channels that function independently of ADH.
  • Option B. Descending limb of the loop of Henle - Incorrect because tubular fluid becomes hypertonic in this segment as water moves out via aquaporin-1 channels into the hypertonic medullary interstitium. ADH status does not significantly affect this segment.
  • Option C. Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle - Incorrect because while this segment does create hypotonic fluid by actively transporting Na+, K+, and Cl- out of the tubule without water (it's water-impermeable), the tubular fluid becomes even more dilute as it continues through the distal tubule and collecting duct in the absence of ADH.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The late distal tubule and collecting duct display the lowest tubular fluid osmolality in central diabetes insipidus because these segments, which normally concentrate urine under ADH influence, remain impermeable to water without ADH, allowing maximally dilute fluid to be excreted.

choices.text: Barrier methods for 4 months and then Semen analysis to confirm
Barrier methods for 3 months and then Semen analysis to confirm
Barrier methods for 4 months with no need to come back
Barrier methods for 3 months with no need to come back

questions.text: Which of the following guidelines are true for the client post-vasectomy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Barrier methods for 3 months and then Semen analysis to confirm

 

After vasectomy, a person is not immediately sterile. It takes 3 months for spermatozoa to clear from the reproductive tract. During this period, the client must use barrier methods of contraception. After 3 months, semen analysis should be done to confirm the success of sterilization.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-vasectomy guidelines require:

 

  1. Use of barrier methods for 3 months
  2. Mandatory semen analysis after 3 months to confirm success of sterilization

choices.text: Distance between Z lines stays the same
