questions.text: Which of the following statements is true according to the sliding filament theory of muscle contraction? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. A band length remains constant

 

Explanation:

 

The sliding filament theory explains that muscle contraction occurs when thin filaments (actin) slide over thick filaments (myosin). During this process, the A band, which represents the region where thick myosin filaments are located, maintains a constant length. This is a fundamental principle of the sliding filament mechanism - the thick and thin filaments themselves don't change in length during contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Myosin filaments become wider - This is incorrect. The myosin filaments maintain their structural dimensions during contraction. The shortening of the muscle is due to increased overlap between filaments, not changes in filament width.
  • Option B. I band  expands- While the I band does shorten during contraction,rather than expanding this is a consequence of the sliding mechanism
  • Option D. Distance between Z lines stays the same - This is incorrect. The Z-lines move closer together during contraction, which is precisely how the muscle generates force and shortens. The distance between Z-lines decreases as contraction proceeds.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In muscle contraction, the A band length remains constant while the relative positions of other sarcomere components change, demonstrating how muscle generates force without changing the length of the contractile proteins themselves.

questions.text: In which type of hysterectomy, is the risk of ureteric injury the least? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vaginal

 

The risk of ureteric injury is least in vaginal hysterectomy compared to other approaches. This is due to the anatomical relationship between the ureter and uterine vessels. The ureter passes underneath the uterine artery (bridge over water concept) approximately 1.5-2 cm lateral to the uterus at the level of the isthmus. When performing a vaginal hysterectomy, the operating field and surgical dissection remains close to the uterus, reducing the risk of encountering and injuring the ureter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparotomy: Incorrect because in abdominal approach (laparotomy), there is a higher risk of ureteric injury due to wider dissection and direct visualization of the area where ureter crosses under the uterine vessels.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy: Incorrect as laparoscopic approach, despite better visualization, still carries a higher risk of ureteric injury compared to vaginal approach due to the extensive lateral dissection required.

 

Option C. Robotic: Incorrect because robotic approach, similar to laparoscopy, involves lateral pelvic dissection which increases risk of ureteric injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk of ureteric injury in increasing order is:

 

  • Vaginal hysterectomy (least risk)
  • Abdominal hysterectomy 
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomy
  • Radical hysterectomy (highest)

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient after receiving haloperidol developed torticollis and dystonia. What will be the best drug in this situation? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Give benzhexol (anticholinergic)

 

Explanation

 

The patient has developed extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), which are side effects commonly associated with antipsychotic medications like haloperidol. EPS can include dystonia (muscle contractions causing twisting and repetitive movements or abnormal postures) and torticollis (a type of dystonia involving the neck muscles).

 

Benzhexol, also known as trihexyphenidyl, is an anticholinergic drug that is effective in treating EPS, including acute dystonic reactions. Anticholinergics help to balance the neurotransmitters in the brain, thereby reducing the symptoms of EPS.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Increase haloperidol dose: This would likely worsen the EPS.

 

Option B. Change haloperidol to clozapine: While clozapine has a lower risk of EPS, this is not an immediate treatment for the acute dystonia.

 

Option D. Change haloperidol to fluphenazine: Fluphenazine, like haloperidol, is a potent dopamine receptor blocker and would likely exacerbate the EPS.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The immediate treatment for drug-induced dystonia is the administration of anticholinergic drugs like benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl).
